title: Can you outsmart this logical fallacy? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was Lucy's major in college?
In studies, what percentage of participants chose the equivalent of the statement "Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Lucy has an affinity for art

options.label: B
options.text: Because the first statement is a less specific version of the second statement

options.label: C
options.text: Because Lucy is more likely to play poker

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon known as the conjunction fallacy?

options.label: A
options.text: When we tend to look for what seems plausible rather than what is statistically most probable

options.label: B
options.text: When we choose the option that seems more representative of the overall picture, regardless of its actual probability

options.label: C
options.text: When we ignore the least likely component of a story

options.label: D
options.text: When we add more conditions to an event to make it more likely

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the likelihood of an event when more conditions are added?
Why do statements with more conditions sometimes seem more believable?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are statistically more probable

options.label: B
options.text: Because they provide a narrative that resonates with our intuitions

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more representative of the overall picture

multiple-choice.question: Who is more likely to fall victim to the conjunction fallacy?

options.label: A
options.text: Only those who are unfamiliar with statistics

options.label: B
options.text: Only those who are familiar with statistics

options.label: C
options.text: Anyone, regardless of their understanding of statistics

options.label: D
options.text: Only experts in a particular field

multiple-choice.question: What type of stories often rely on a version of the conjunction fallacy to seem credible?

options.label: B
options.text: Conspiracy theories and false news stories

multiple-choice.question: What determines the likelihood that a story is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of resonant details added to the story

options.label: B
options.text: The probability that its least likely component is true

options.label: C
options.text: The number of people who believe the story

multiple-choice.question: What happens when we choose an option based on the conjunction fallacy?

options.label: A
options.text: We choose the most statistically probable option

options.label: B
options.text: We choose the option that seems most plausible

options.label: C
options.text: We choose the option that is most representative of the overall picture

options.label: D
options.text: We choose the option that is least likely to be true
